sense.name: Draw something in by or as if by suction
sense.commentary: NOTE: Compare to sense 4. This sense does not include metaphorically taking in, or taking in without suction.
sense.examples: You must suck out the poison - there's no time to wait! Try to suck on a straw. The baby sucked on the mother's breast. Mud was sucking at her feet. A giant vacuum sucks away the dried mud and burnt wrappers. The current boom in the economy sucked many workers in from abroad. Suck out the wound using the pipette. Suck in your cheeks and stomach.

sense.name: Be inadequate or objectionable.
sense.examples: This sucks! That class really sucked.

sense.name: Provide sexual gratification through oral stimulation.
sense.examples: Dental dams should be used whenever a partner chooses to suck. No woman should ever feel obligated to suck a partner off.

sense.name: Take in; also metaphorically.
sense.commentary: Note: Compare to sense 1. This sense does not include sucking in through the mouth or through another object that creates suction.
sense.examples: The sponge sucked (up) moisture. The desert air sucks the moisture right out of you.

sense.name: Ingratiate oneself to; try to gain favor by flattering.
sense.examples: She is sucking up to the chairman. He sucked up to his boss for years before landing a promotion.

sense.name: Give suck to.
sense.examples: You can't suck your baby in public in some places.
